attributes.title: The Reasons Illinois Tool Works Is More Valuable Than Its Peers
summary: ITW operates in a cyclical industry that is prone to the ups and downs of macroeconomic activity. ITW shares will probably perform inline with the market.
ITW is trading at a higher price multiple compared to its peers, still, it is fairly valued based on fundamentals.
There are four reasons ITW is attracting higher valuations; higher dividend yields, higher profit margin, lower debt and an investor-friendly share repurchase program.

attributes.content:
Investment Thesis

Illinois Tool Works (NYSE:ITW) operates in a cyclical industry and the company's performance is tied to the general level of economic activity. ITW shares are a macro play as much as they are a company-specific trade.

Having said that, I think that the naysayer had it wrong about the company's valuation. There are four good reasons the company trades above industry-average price multiples.

  1. Higher dividend yield
  2. Lower leverage
  3. Higher margins
  4. Share repurchases

I believe that ITW shares will perform in line with the broader market.

Company overview

If there is one word to describe ITW, it would be decentralized. The company consists of hundreds of small businesses that build:

  1. Automobile parts
  2. Kitchen appliances (refrigerators, dishwashers)
  3. Test & Measurement and Electronics
  4. Welding products
  5. Chemicals
  6. Construction products

The decentralized structure is important, given the diverse end markets that ITW serves. The businesses are autonomous as can be, given the company's strategic plans. The company sells branded products such as Hobart, Miller Electric, Paslode, and unbranded parts used by companies such as Ford (F) and Boeing (BA).

The company's performance will depend on the level of activity in its end markets established above.

Revenue Analysis

In the first quarter, economic disruptions in China and other parts of Asia negatively affected ITW's revenue, which declined 10% during the quarter.

Revenue from auto parts was hit the hardest decreasing 13.6%, as car manufacturers decreased car build-ups in anticipation of lower demand due to the pandemic.

In the second quarter, revenues were down 26% as the pandemic reached Europe and the U.S. Sales from the auto parts and kitchen appliances segments decreased the most as car manufacturers lowered production and restaurants closed, in keeping with the lockdown rules.

In the third quarter, revenue increased considerably compared to the previous quarter but was 4% lower compared to the same quarter last year. The sequential improvement was in line with the general economic activity as governments lifted social distancing rules. The construction and chemicals segment improved the most, and sales from these two segments were higher than the previous quarter last year, partially offsetting the year-on-year decline in the other segments.

I imagine that the construction sector saw an increase in demand as construction contractors ramped up work to compensate for the forgone time during the lockdown. The chemicals sector improved as manufacturers stocked in raw materials and built inventories in anticipation of higher production demand.

Peer Comparison

TWI trades on a higher price multiple than its peers. Dover Corp. (DOV), Fortive Corp. (FTV), and Parker-Hannifin Corp (PH) all have a similar revenue growth rate to TWI. Still, all trade at a lower PE ratio than the company.

The first possible explanation for ITW's above-average valuation is its low debt. Among its peers with comparable revenue growth, TWI has the lowest debt to equity ratio.

Another possible reason for the higher PE is the dividend yield. Again, it has a higher dividend ratio among its peers.

TWI has the highest profit margin. The company touts its management strategy which focuses on value-added products that allow the company to charge higher margins.

Share repurchase

9-months ending Sept. 2020 2019 2018 2017
Share repurchases (millions) $706 $1,500 $2,000 $1,000

Sourced from company financial statements

The company has an investor-friendly share repurchase program that supports its share price and valuation. I expect the company to purchase around $300 million in the fourth quarter, bringing the year's total purchases in line with the historical average.

The number of shares has been declining for the past ten years as a result of the share repurchase program as shown below.

How I might be wrong

I argue in this piece that ITW will perform in line with the market, contrary to a broadly-held view that the company is overvalued. I might be wrong, and shares of ITW might underperform the market for the following reasons.

One possible risk is the digitalization trends that push tech stock higher, while industrial stocks remain flat. We have seen this happening in the second quarter, as lockdown rules led to a surge in demand for digital solutions. Many analysts expect digitalization trends to continue, and the general market might outperform ITW, especially given the weight of tech stock in many indexes.

Half of ITW's revenues come from abroad, exposing the company to currency risks. Central banks around the world ventured on unprecedented monetary easing which might destabilize currency rates. We have seen the value of gold (XAUUSD:CUR) surge this year as monetary risks rise. There hasn't been a major disruption yet, but sometimes, monetary imbalances take time to boil into a market disruptive event. These risks are more serious for cyclical stocks such as ITW.

The high dividend, share repurchases, high margins, and low debt are all factors that justify ITW's price premium. But this analysis is based given a certain level of growth that the company was able to secure in the past five years. If management growth initiates fail, or if investors perceive them to be unsuccessful, shares might underperform the market.

Finally, if the results of the fourth quarter disappoint investors, ITW might fall. This is a real possibility given the recent increase in COVID infections and subsequent lockdowns and social distancing rules which might translate to lower demand in the fourth quarter. The company usually announces fourth quarter results in the last week of January.

Summary

ITW is a manufacturing conglomerate with a strong balance sheet and international operations that enabled it to withstand the pandemic. Still, the cyclical nature of its operations means that ITW's shares will perform in line with the general market.

ITW is trading at higher price multiples than its peers. This is possible because of its lower debt, higher dividends, profit margins, and an investor-friendly share repurchase program. I believe that ITW's shares will maintain this premium above its peers' shares.
